text: [Music]
it's a good question because I think it
is um there is uh there are two things
about it number one is there's no um
straightforward recipe um but there are
things that we recognize we can do um I
think number one it's to rec to
understand
that um making the system work well is
something that we're only starting to
Grapple with medicine has been about
Parts it's been about having a great
drug a great doctor it has only in the
last few years started to become about
making all of that fit together as well
as possible and the most important role
I think that patients play is um they're
the only ones that see when things are
falling through the cracks you see one
specialist and then another specialist
but they don't talk to each other and
what they're telling you doesn't make
sense or fit together um a third of
patients by the end of their life have
10 or more specialists in their care and
um we're not very good at knitting all
of that together um and so I think the
the most important part the patient
plays is um not being passive about
their part on the team they are um we're
not great at drawing out the patient
we've wanted the patient to be passive
and and not so involved um just do what
we say but the more we have different
people involved um what we tell people
is contradictory it doesn't always help
them the way it should and um as we get
our act together I think what we're
learning is the patients play a key role
one thing that I tell people is if you
have a sick family member don't leave
them alone in the hospital um even when
there are visiting hours where you know
you're supposed to go home I I'll tell
people find any way you can to stay
anyway because when you're sick is the
last moment when um uh when as a patient
you're able to fend for yourself and the
family member is often the person as
shifts change and different people come
and go who'll be the ones to convey you
know my dad actually seemed sicker than
he did yesterday you'll be surprised
about the extent to which just having
those kinds of eyes and ears are missing
with the slew of people coming and going
so I um I know it can be unnerving um
it's sort of like when the effort to
trap terrorists falls through and the
passenger has to be the one to tackle
the um the terrorist trying to light the
bomb on the plane in a certain sense um
for an extremely complex system of care
to work well we all have to be part of
the equation um we in medicine have to
be willing to hear from patients who
will challenge us we sometimes have to
be willing to push back and actually on
that one um here's the reason why we're
doing it this way but um it's becoming a
uh a group effort in order to get things
right
